message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms suggestive of peripheral neuropathy, nodules, and non-blanching erythematous lesions on both shins, which are characteristic of Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis. The laboratory values show an elevated white blood cell count with a high percentage of eosinophils, suggesting an eosinophilic disorder. Goodpasture syndrome and Granulomatosis with polyangiitis are less likely based on the clinical presentation. Excessive glucocorticoid use is not a diagnosis, but a potential cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to the given symptoms and laboratory results to determine the most likely diagnosis. The patient is presenting with neurological and dermatological symptoms, as well as fever and elevated white blood cell count with eosinophilia. The tender subcutaneous nodules, non-blanching erythematous lesions on shins, and impaired dorsiflexion of the foot suggest vasculitis. Among the options, only Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Churg-Strauss syndrome) is associated with asthma, subcutaneous nodules, and skin lesions, as well as systemic vasculitis with multi-organ involvement. The elevated creatinine and proteinuria suggest potential renal involvement. Glucocorticoid use can cause similar symptoms, but the patient's recent onset and lack of history of excessive use make it unlikely. Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by glomerulonephritis and lung hemorrhage, which are not evident in this patient. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis can present with similar symptoms, but typically has a different pattern of organ involvement and does not have marked eosinophilia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms suggestive of neurological involvement (impaired dorsiflexion of the right foot and decreased sensation on the ulnar aspect of the left forearm) and skin involvement (tender subcutaneous nodules on extensor surfaces of the elbows, and palpable erythematous lesions on both shins). Additionally, the laboratory studies reveal an elevated leukocyte count with a significant eosinophilia, proteinuria, and elevated creatinine. All of these findings suggest Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), formerly known as Churg-Strauss Syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including the subcutaneous nodules, non-blanching erythematous lesions, and impaired dorsiflexion of the right foot, suggest Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), previously known as Churg-Strauss syndrome. The laboratory findings, including an elevated eosinophil count, also support this diagnosis. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis and Goodpasture syndrome do not typically present with the same symptoms as EGPA, and excessive glucocorticoid use would not cause the physical findings seen in this patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, also known as Churg-Strauss syndrome. The nodules on the extensor surfaces of elbows, non-blanching erythematous lesions on shins, and impaired dorsiflexion of right foot are consistent with the syndrome. The high eosinophil count and elevated serum creatinine suggest renal involvement. The history of chronic sinusitis and recent asthma diagnosis may also be associated with the syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of peripheral neuropathy, pulmonary and skin involvement, and a high percentage of eosinophils in the blood. These are all characteristic of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Churg-Strauss syndrome). The laboratory results also show elevated creatinine and protein in urine, indicating renal involvement. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis may also present similarly but with a different type of white blood cell predominance (primarily neutrophils) and without a high percentage of eosinophils. Goodpasture syndrome is another possibility, but it typically presents with pulmonary and renal involvement without skin and peripheral nerve involvement. Excessive glucocorticoid use would not explain the constellation of symptoms and laboratory findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest a systemic inflammatory disorder, and there are tender subcutaneous nodules and erythematous lesions on both shins. The impaired dorsiflexion of the right foot and decreased sensation over the ulnar aspect of the left forearm suggest peripheral nerve involvement. The high eosinophil count and proteinuria suggest eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis. None of the other options match the patient's symptoms and laboratory results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, laboratory results, and physical examination suggest the most likely diagnosis of Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), also known as Churg-Strauss syndrome. The history of chronic sinusitis and asthma may be associated with EGPA, and the presence of tender subcutaneous nodules on the extensor surfaces of the elbows and palpable, non-blanching erythematous lesions on both shins are characteristic skin findings. The decreased sensation over the ulnar aspect of the left forearm may be due to peripheral neuropathy, which is a common manifestation of EGPA. The elevated eosinophil count in the laboratory studies also suggests the diagnosis of EGPA.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows symptoms such as difficulty walking, subcutaneous nodules, erythematous lesions, impaired dorsiflexion, and decreased sensation, which are consistent with Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), also known as Churg-Strauss Syndrome. Elevated eosinophils in laboratory studies also support the diagnosis. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis and Goodpasture syndrome are less likely based on the information provided. Excessive glucocorticoid use is possible but not the most likely diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a neurological deficit, and the laboratory studies show an elevated eosinophil count and decreased kidney function, which are characteristic of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Churg-Strauss syndrome). Goodpasture syndrome and granulomatosis with polyangiitis typically do not present with subcutaneous nodules and erythematous lesions on the shins, and excessive glucocorticoid use would not explain the neurological deficit and other symptoms.
